<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 415, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 504, 464]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 504, 479]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 478, 380, 494]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 255, 520]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 358, 546]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 767, 561]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 586]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 759, 601]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR) separated from a source of light by different depths of water as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 134, 702, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between the resistance \(R\) of the LDR and the depth \(d\) of the LDR in the water is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 425, 541, 454]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{4\pi d^2}{K}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 472, 303, 488]]<|/det|>
where \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 502, 920, 550]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(R\) and \(d\). Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(K\). You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 395, 581]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 587, 415, 603]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 353, 625]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 632, 356, 648]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 448, 670]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 668, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating how the forces acting on a bridge vary as the position of a load on the bridge is changed. The bridge is modelled as shown in Fig. 2.1 with two newton-meters providing the support forces.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 128, 819, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 396, 532, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
A load of mass \(m\) is placed at a distance \(x\) from support A. The readings of the newton-meters \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) are recorded for different values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 608, 494]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(T_{1}\) , \(T_{2}\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 504, 613, 534]]<|/det|>
\[T_{1} - T_{2} = \frac{mg(s - x) - mgx}{s}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 551, 803, 570]]<|/det|>
where \(s\) is the separation of the newton-meters and \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 146, 601]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 705, 601]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \((T_{1} - T_{2})\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 643, 631]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and the \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 797, 917, 816]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 829, 917, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 512, 91]]<|/det|> Values of \(x\), \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) are given in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 102, 858, 344]]<|/det|>
\(x/m\)\(T_{1}/N\)\(T_{2}/N\)
0.1006.9 ± 0.11.4 ± 0.1
0.1606.4 ± 0.11.8 ± 0.1
0.2205.9 ± 0.12.3 ± 0.1
0.2805.5 ± 0.12.7 ± 0.1
0.3405.0 ± 0.13.1 ± 0.1
0.4004.6 ± 0.13.3 ± 0.1
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 358, 534, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 389, 601, 408]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \((T_{1} - T_{2}) / \mathrm{N}\) in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 539, 426]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \((T_{1} - T_{2})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 426]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 144, 458]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 439, 180, 458]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 439, 529, 458]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \((T_{1} - T_{2}) / \mathrm{N}\) against \(x / \mathrm{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 452, 476]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \((T_{1} - T_{2})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 457, 920, 476]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 481, 178, 500]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 920, 515]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 501, 920, 518]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 523, 180, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 920, 556]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 817, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
gradient = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[515, 297, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 144, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 327, 178, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 327, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to **(a)**, **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)**, determine the values of \(m\) and \(s\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 371, 366, 390]]<|/det|>
Data: \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[586, 547, 917, 565]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[593, 578, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
<form>s = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 623, 181, 642]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 623, 618, 642]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 806, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
